climbs.name: When the Bible is a Bottle

content.description:
Another Drysdale classic! This fantastically powerful, yet delicate problem is not to be missed.

 Starts to the left of Booze Pig. Start with a distinct two finger sidepull/undercling with the left hand. Move up through hard to hold crimps to a bigger move over the bulge to stick a positive"V" shaped hold. Gun it to the large sloping rail and try to figure out how to mantle towards or dyno to the large lonely pocket way above you. This one ain't over till it's over.
content.protection: Wild swings, extra pads and spotters are nice.
content.location: Middle left of the Booze Pig Wall

content.description: Super cool problem, that might be a little height dependent.  Cool dyno to a jug and moderately good holds to the top of the wall.  Watch out for flappers!
content.location: starts off prominent undercling to the right of Booze Pig and OLISMLD, big move up to jug and then finageling your way to the top of the wall

content.description: Real kiddie climbing! A great line of huecos and ledges to challenge the wee ones.
content.protection: a good strong hand under your buns!
content.location: Far right side of the wall

content.description:
Starts to the right of Tomorrow Never Comes on bulging face with faint orange streak. Move up to a positive right side pull, and a two finger left hand crimp flake. Get the feet way up, and toss to a good, though slightly hidden two finger pocket way up and left, finish straight up.

 A cool problem once you figure it out. Big ol backstep.... There are a couple of warmups to the right. The name is an old timey way of ordering a drink.
content.location: Middle right side of the wall.

content.description: This line starts to the right of Undercling Fling. Look for dueling 5/16" crimps off the ground below a conspicuous left facing reddish jug/ horn. Launch up with the right hand, and enjoy good finger buckets to top out. Pretty good climbing for the grade.
content.location: To the right of Undercling Fling.

content.description:
To the right of Booze Pig and left of On Liquor I Spent My Last Dime, is a very thin line of positive crimps which leads to a perfect 3" round pocket. The pocket turns out to be just another crimp.

 Easily identified by the scar on the face where a larger sized flake pealed off the wall.

climbs.name: On Liquor I Spent my Last Dime

content.description:
Another classic on a wall loaded with them!

 This line is 8' or so to the right of Booze Pig, and just right of Punch Drunk Sunrise. This is a classic wingspan problem. They didn't call Rob the Condor for nothing. Look for a very typical, and sharp two finger pocket on the bulge for the left hand. Get your feet up, and launch upwards towards a good, right facing sidepull jug with the right hand. There is a crimp, right on the top of this hold, and the direct finish up and left, staying well left of the top of Undercling Fling is the way to go.

 You can start this line below the large side pull if you can’t span the regular start.  I don't think it changes the grade.
content.location: Right end of Booze pig wall, where wall starts to get steep and over hung.

content.description: At $5 a 12'er, this was the best beer in high school! Off the skirt, climb up to that sketchy looking black block
content.protection: how ever many pads you brought up
content.location: Where the skirt meets the dirt

content.description: Start for Booze Pig and then climb into When the Bible is a Bottle before making the big throw. Unlike every other climb on the wall, the crux of this climb is not the throw around the bulge. Instead, this line forces creative and/or powerful movement to get set up with your right hand on the crimp rail on Booze Pig. From here, the v-notch hold on WTBIAB is a manageable reach to the left, with obvious crimps to bump from. IMO this climb is probably the least height dependent route up this wall and makes for a fun link-up. I doubt I'm the first to think of the link, but I've been convinced by others to add it to the page for everyone to enjoy.

To the left of A Hardwood Floor Is Home are a couple yuccas. Left of these is a large chunky flake. Climb up this feature to, yes you guessed it, another challenging bulge encounter. Doesn't get done a whole lot.

A Flagstaff classic, especially for the grade. Booze Pig is a devious line which will test your finger strength, body tension, and clarity of mind.

 Start with right hand two finger "tooth" looking undercling pocket. This hold is not your typical pocket, and is a bit sharp. Move up and left with good feet to the conspicuous slopey crimp rail (The Lighting Bolt hold of Flagstaff) on the bulge. Do a tenuous match and then deadpoint the slopey, toothy crimp hold. One more big move to a perfect finger bucket up and left delivers you into the insecure, punch drunk feeling topout... Twenty+ years old and still kicking ass.
content.location: Center of the Booze Pig wall, left of OLISMLD, behind scraggly juniper.

content.description: Climb up to and passed the crescent moon hold to an undercling and the ledge, easy mantle
content.location: Left of Empty as a Pocket, on the other side of the bush

content.description: To the left of When the Bible is a Bottle find another line of small crimps to a big toss up and over the bulge, followed by another hard mantle. Though the rock on this line looks good, the bulge is hollow...
content.location: Just left of The Bible is a Bottle

pathTokens: Land of High Bouldering AKA The Ridge

content.description:
The Booze Pig Wall is a collage of legend and history, of myth and mystery. The wall itself looks like a cresting wave captured in stone and time. A wave that will quickly feel like it is crashing down on you if your tips are not up for the challenges of such classic Drysdale problems as On Liquor I Spent my Last Dime V5, Booze Pig V6, When the Bible is a Bottle V7, and The Hardwood Floor is Home V8.

 This is "Ridge" bouldering distilled down to the purest movement possible, and these technical lines will certainly test the skills of most. Though not truly high ball, finishing these bad boys up will require a calm head, a little foot faith, and probably result in moments of clarity. A beautiful place to stretch it out, and take it all in.
